title: Basal Cell Carcinoma
diagnosis_topic: Pearly, slow-growing skin lesion consistent with basal cell carcinoma
setup_script: “A 60-year-old woman with fair skin presents with a 5 mm pearly papule with telangiectasia on the bridge of her nose. It has been present for one year and has slowly enlarged. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: Translucent nodule with rolled borders and central depression; no ulceration.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about sun exposure and risk factors
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient reports years of outdoor work without sunscreen.
Shows arborizing vessels typical of basal cell carcinoma.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays workup or does not address lesion
dynamic_flow.reply: Over next 6 months, lesion doubles in size and begins ulcerating.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs shave or punch biopsy
dynamic_flow.reply: Pathology confirms nodular basal cell carcinoma.
Lesion continues to enlarge, with progressive local tissue involvement.
Options include surgical excision with 4 mm margins or Mohs micrographic surgery for cosmetic areas.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident recommends wide local excision with 4 mm margins
dynamic_flow.reply: Appropriate, but may risk cosmetic defect on nasal bridge.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident recommends Mohs micrographic surgery
dynamic_flow.reply: Preferred for lesions on the face to maximize tissue conservation and ensure clear margins.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs inappropriate management (e.g., cryotherapy only)
dynamic_flow.reply: Lesion recurs within months and enlarges.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident provides postoperative care instructions
dynamic_flow.reply: Wound care, suture removal and scar management discussed.
Recurrence is low after complete excision but higher with positive margins or certain subtypes.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident educates about sun protection
dynamic_flow.reply: Regular sunscreen use, protective clothing, and avoidance of tanning beds.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident screens for other skin lesions
dynamic_flow.reply: Full skin exam performed to look for additional actinic damage or lesions.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident differentiates from squamous cell carcinoma and melanoma
dynamic_flow.reply: Examiner requests resident to compare differences in appearance and metastatic potential.

critical_decision_points: Recognition and biopsy of suspicious skin lesions
Selection of appropriate treatment modality (excision vs. Mohs)
Patient counseling on sun protection and surveillance
Understanding recurrence risk and histologic subtypes
Performing a full skin examination to identify additional lesions

resident_feedback_template: Strengths: You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by recognizing the characteristic features of basal cell carcinoma and confirming the diagnosis with biopsy. You appropriately discussed surgical management options and emphasized the role of Mohs surgery for cosmetically sensitive areas.Areas for Improvement: Earlier recognition of the importance of timely biopsy and more detailed explanation of recurrence risks and histologic subtypes would strengthen your management. Comprehensive counseling on sun protection and secondary lesion screening should be consistently included.Suggested Reading Topics: - SCORE: Non-melanoma Skin Cancer - American Cancer Society: Surgical Management of Basal Cell Carcinoma - ACS/ASE Review Manual: Principles of Skin Cancer Excision and Mohs Surgery
